Award.AwardTitle: How is pheromone stereochemistry regulated in Ips bark beetles
Award.AbstractNarration: Bark beetles are among the most significant economic pests in North America, causing the loss of billions of board feet of timber each year and adding to the fuel load that contributed to the devastating wild fires in the western U.S. over the past several decades. The long term goal of this project is to develop new and effective pest management tactics based on pheromone systems (chemical secretions produced by the beetles). Except for a brief pheromone directed flight, bark beetles spend the majority of their lives protected beneath the bark of the trees they colonize and kill. Pheromones are essential for beetles to mount the mass attack that leads to tree death. This research project is designed to gain a better understanding of the biochemical processes by which bark beetles produce pheromones. Bark beetles produce pheromone components in the midgut by mobilizing and up-regulating the enzymes of the mevalonate pathway and by specialization of the enzymes that detoxify tree defensive chemicals. The final steps in pheromone production involve changing the stereochemistry of terpenoid alcohols to achieve the final blend that functions as the pheromone. This project is designed to characterize these enzymes. In addition, a post-doctoral fellow, a graduate student, and several undergraduates will be trained during the work on the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bark beetles in the family Scolytidae (Coleoptera) are among the most significant and important pest insects in the United States. Bark beetles are the most destructive pests of sawtimber and pulpwood in the the Northern hemisphere. They kill millions of cubic meters of conifer trees in production forests and are a keystone species in natural ecosystems by initiating the process of nutrient recycling of mature trees.  Bark beetles use aggregation pheromones to coordinate 'mass' attacks on trees in order to overcome the tree's defense mechanisms. The objectives of this grant were to understand the final steps in pheromone production in bark beetles.

Ips species bark beetles use ipsdienol and ipsenol as aggregation pheromones in specific enatiomeric ratios. In the course of this work, we have characterized a number of key genes in pheromone production, including a unique geranyl diphosphate synthase, a cytochrome P450 that hydroxylates myrcene and a novel ipsdienol dehydrogenase that catalyzes the last steps in pheromone production. We determined substrate specificity and kinetic parameters and showed that this enzyme had high substrate specificity for converting ipsdienone to the pheromone ipsdienol.

We used 'RNA-seq' to examine the up-regulation of the genes involved in pheromone production and to isolate the gene that is responible for the conversion of ipsdienone to ipsenone, a key step in pheromone production in some species. All of the expected steps in pheromone production had their RNA levels up-regulated by 50 to 1000 fold in pheromone producing fed male pinion ips compared to unfed controls, with one step, the gene that is responsible for converting myrcene to ipsdienol up-regulated one thousand fold. Future work will be done to examine and express other key genes involved in pheromone production with goal to use this work to find novel methods to control beetle outbreaks..
